resources.string: Rate this app on Google Play
A small status indicator that displays a number or status atop other components.
A bar anchored at the bottom of the screen with navigation and action items.
A surface that slides up from the bottom to reveal additional content.
Tap targets that trigger actions when pressed by the user.
Surfaces that group related content and actions into distinct containers.
A control that toggles between checked and unchecked states for binary choices.
Compact elements that represent an input, attribute, or action.
A dialog or inline component for selecting a date from a calendar.
Modal windows that inform users and require a response.
Thin lines used to separate content or groups within layouts.
A floating action button that includes both an icon and a text label.
A circular floating action button that triggers a primary action.
Buttons that contain only an icon and no text label.
Vertical collections of items, often scrollable and comprised of multiple elements.
Temporary surfaces that display a list of choices or actions.
A bar at the bottom of the screen providing top-level navigation between views.
A sliding panel that presents app-level navigation options.
A vertical component offering top-level navigation, ideal for larger screens.
Visual indicators that show the progress of ongoing tasks.
A control that allows a single selection from a list of options.
An input field where users can enter text to search content.
A group of horizontally aligned buttons where only one can be selected.
Controls that let users select a value by dragging a thumb along a track.
Brief messages that appear at the bottom of the screen, informing users of an action.
A control for toggling between two states, such as on and off.
Horizontal rows of tabs that allow users to navigate between different views or content sections.
Input fields where users can enter and edit text.
A dialog or inline component for selecting a time of day.
A bar at the top of the screen containing navigation and action items.
Explore other UI elements you might find useful.

Badges are typically placed on the ending edge of icons and used to indicate a notification or item count. They are most commonly used within other components, such as navigation bar, navigation rail, app bars, and tabs.
Use small (dot) badges for simple attention indicators and larger badges to display numeric counts.
Note: the text on a large badge should be no longer than four characters.

Material 3 offer five button variants: Elevated, Filled, Tonal, Outlined, and Text. Each variant may include an optional icon. Button labels should use sentence case and be no longer than three words. Additionally, buttons can appear with square corners instead of rounded ones, and can be shown in a disabled state.
Elevated buttons provide separation from a visually prominent background. Buttons at higher elevations typically have more emphasis in a design, and should be used sparingly.

Filled buttons have high visual impact when used for important actions. It should be used for important, final actions that complete a flow, like Save or Confirm. Since they have such strong emphasis, the filled style should be used sparingly, ideally for only one action on a page.

The tonal style has less emphasis than filled or elevated. The tonal button style is useful in contexts where a lower-priority button requires slightly more emphasis than an outline would give, such as Next in an onboarding flow.

"The outlined style is ideal for medium-emphasis buttons which contain actions that are important, but aren't the primary action in a product. Outlined buttons pair well with filled buttons to indicate alternative, secondary actions."

The text button style should be used for the lowest priority actions, especially when presenting multiple options. They should be placed on simple backgrounds and are often placed within components such as cards, dialogs, and snackbars.
Checkboxes let users select one or more items from a list. They are ideal for scenarios requiring multiple or nested selections.
A parent checkbox enables users to quickly select or deselect all associated child options.
Date pickers let people select a date or a range of dates.
Dividers are thin lines that separate or group content. There are two orientations (horizontal and vertical). Use them sparingly to create clear visual breaks without overcrowding.

Full width dividers are used to separate larger sections of unrelated content. They can be used directly on a surface or inside other components like cards or lists. Full width dividers can also separate interactive areas from non-interactive areas.
Inset dividers can separate related content within a section. They are equally indented from both sides of the screen by default.
Lists are vertically organized collections of text and images. They optimize readability and can include primary or supplemental actions represented by icons or text.
List items come in three variants: one-line, two-line, and three-line.
"Note: Controls display information and actions for list itemsâ€”such as checkboxes and switches. They can be part of a list item's leading or trailing content."
Supporting text that spans multiple lines and is truncated with an ellipsis
Radio buttons let users select exactly one option from a list. Use them when you want to expose all available choices and enforce a single selection.
They must always include clear inline labels.
Switches let users adjust settings and other standalone options. They make a binary selection, like on and off or true and false, and the effects of a switch should be immediate.
They must always include clear inline labels. The switch can have optional icons for both checked and unchecked states.
